articles.headline: F.D.I.C. Chairwoman to Leave in July
articles.snippet: The agency announced that Sheila C. Bair will end her five-year term on July 8.
articles.abstract: The agency announced that Sheila C. Bair will end her five-year term on July 8.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sheila C. Bair, one of the banking industry’s most influential regulators and outspoken critics during the financial crisis, said on Monday that she planned to step down as chairwoman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on July 8.

articles.headline: Japan’s Nuclear Future in the Balance
articles.snippet: The accident at the Fukushima Daiichi plant may cause Japan to import more fossil fuels rather than increase its reliance on renewable energy sources, experts say.
articles.abstract: The accident at the Fukushima Daiichi plant may cause Japan to import more fossil fuels rather than increase its reliance on renewable energy sources, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The accident at the Fukushima Daiichi power plant has done more than spew radiation into the air and sea and force tens of thousands of people to evacuate their homes. It has blown a big hole in Japan’s energy policy, which had assumed that nuclear power would supply a growing part of the country’s needs.

articles.headline: The Real Cost of Airline Travel Remains a Mystery, for Now
articles.snippet: The Transportation Department is moving to require airlines to release much more detailed information about all those extra fees they’ve been collecting in recent years.
articles.abstract: The Transportation Department is moving to require airlines to release much more detailed information about all those extra fees they’ve been collecting in recent years.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Transportation Department is moving to require airlines to release much more detailed information about all those extra fees they’ve been collecting in recent years.

articles.headline: Social Networks Offer a Way to Narrow the Field of Friends
articles.snippet: When Facebook is too public, smaller sites let a user share news with a streamlined group of people.
articles.abstract: When Facebook is too public, smaller sites let a user share news with a streamlined group of people.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are times when you just have to tell your friends about something — but not necessarily your Facebook friends.
articles.byline: By Jenna Wortham and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Gingrich Set to Run, With Wife in Central Role
articles.snippet: Newt Gingrich and his wife, Callista, began dating while he was still married, but associates now believe she can be helpful to his campaign if he runs for president.
articles.abstract: Newt Gingrich and his wife, Callista, began dating while he was still married, but associates now believe she can be helpful to his campaign if he runs for president.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Callista Bisek’s friends from rural Wisconsin were stunned when, well over a decade ago, she confided that she was secretly dating an older, married man: Newt Gingrich.

articles.headline: U.S. Was Braced for Fight With Pakistanis in Bin Laden Raid
articles.snippet: President Obama insisted that the force hunting down Osama bin Laden last week be large enough to fight its way out of Pakistan if confronted by local forces.
articles.abstract: President Obama insisted that the force hunting down Osama bin Laden last week be large enough to fight its way out of Pakistan if confronted by local forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by  Eric Schmitt,  Thom Shanker and  David E. Sanger.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, Thom Shanker and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Catching Scent of Revolution, China Moves to Snip Jasmine
articles.snippet: Since Tunisian revolutionaries anointed their successful revolt the “Jasmine Revolution,” the flowering cousin of the olive tree has been branded a nefarious change-agent.
articles.abstract: Since Tunisian revolutionaries anointed their successful revolt the “Jasmine Revolution,” the flowering cousin of the olive tree has been branded a nefarious change-agent.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAXING, China — Do not be lulled by its intoxicating fragrance or the dainty, starlike blossoms whose whiteness suggests innocence and purity. Jasmine, a stalwart of Chinese tea and the subject of a celebrated folk song often heard while on hold with provincial bureaucrats, is not what it seems.
articles.byline: By Andrew Jacobs and Jonathan Ansfield
